questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

E) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.
Image Description:

MR angiography (right carotid artery)

There is severe stenosis (hatched green overlay) of the proximal internal carotid artery.

1: superior thyroid artery; 2: lingual artery; 3: facial artery
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided weakness and subjective decreased sensation that started 30 minutes ago. The patient reports that his symptoms started to ease 5 minutes after onset and have now completely resolved. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (220 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. He appears well. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac examination shows regular rate and rhythm and a left-sided carotid bruit. Complete blood count, serum glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and left axis deviation. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Carotid doppler ultrasound shows 45% stenosis in the left carotid artery and 15% stenosis in the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks are not recommended because the patient has a high risk of stroke and requires treatment. Risk factors for cerebral ischemia in this patient include age > 60 years, blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg, unilateral weakness, diabetes mellitus, and symptoms lasting > 10 minutes.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended in TIA for symptomatic patients who present with carotid stenosis ≥ 70%. Carotid endarterectomy is warranted in asymptomatic patients if the stenosis is ≥ 80%. CEA should also be considered in select patients with moderate stenosis (50–69%) depending on the patient's age, sex, and comorbidities, but the procedure is generally not indicated if the degree of stenosis is < 50%.

C) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram should be part of the workup for a patient with TIA or stroke if there is suspicion of a cardioembolic etiology. This patient has no history of atrial fibrillation that would predispose him to a cardioembolic stroke and his ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, making a cardioembolic etiology of his symptoms unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel is recommended for all patients with a TIA as secondary stroke prevention. A noncontrast CT should be performed beforehand to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. Additional strategies for preventing recurrent TIA or stroke in this patient with carotid artery stenosis include statin therapy and treatment of modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) via lifestyle modifications (e.g., physical activity, dietary interventions, weight loss, smoking cessation) and medications.

Carotid revascularization (e.g., carotid endarterectomy, carotid artery stenting) is contraindicated if carotid artery stenosis is < 50% because the risks from the procedure outweigh any benefits.
Image Description:

MRI angiography (carotid arteries)

There is high-grade stenosis of the origin of the right internal carotid artery (red overlay). Visible major neck vessels (green overlay) include the common carotid arteries (1), internal carotid arteries (2), external carotid arteries (3), right superior thyroid artery (4), and left vertebral artery (5).

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alteplase therapy is recommended for the treatment of ischemic stroke. Although this patient has symptoms consistent with stroke (e.g., weakness and decreased sensation), the symptoms only lasted for 5 minutes; such a short duration is inconsistent with ischemic stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenting can be considered in patients with advanced carotid artery stenosis if a surgical approach is not feasible, e.g., because of poor surgical access to the stenosis or the presence of comorbidities that increase perioperative mortality. The procedure is generally not indicated if the degree of stenosis is < 50%.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden-onset focal neurological deficits that resolved without treatment in combination with no evidence of ischemia on neuroimaging suggest a transient ischemic attack (TIA), for which this patient has numerous risk factors (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, carotid artery stenosis). Two important factors for determining the management of carotid artery stenosis are the degree of stenosis (here < 50%) and if a patient is symptomatic (e.g., experiencing a TIA).

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He goes for a 30-minute walk three times a week and does not experience any shortness of breath or chest or leg pain on exertion. He has not had any weakness, numbness, or vision disturbance. He has diabetes that is well-controlled with insulin injections. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes every day for 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds. There are systolic bruits over the neck bilaterally. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Fasting serum studies show:


Total cholesterol
285 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
32 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
205 mg/dL


Triglycerides
240 mg/dL


Glucose
92 mg/dL


Duplex ultrasonography of the carotid arteries shows an 85% stenosis on the left and a 55% stenosis on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy is used to manage carotid stenosis by reducing the risk of cardiovascular events, such as stroke. While this patient should be placed on aspirin therapy or another antiplatelet agent such as clopidogrel, medical therapy alone would not be recommended in a patient with severe carotid stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin therapy is used to manage carotid stenosis by reducing the risk of cardiovascular events, such as stroke. While this patient should be placed on a long-term statin, medical therapy alone would not be recommended in a patient with severe carotid stenosis.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) should be considered in asymptomatic patients with severe carotid stenosis. The 85% stenosis of the left carotid in this otherwise healthy patient warrants recanalization at this time to prevent future morbidity and mortality. In addition, all patients with carotid artery stenosis should receive medical management comprised of statin therapy, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin or clopidogrel), and treatment of modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) via lifestyle modifications (e.g., physical activity, smoking cessation) and medications.

D) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol therapy is indicated to control hypertension in patients who have carotid artery stenosis. This patient is normotensive and does not require hypertension medication at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is not appropriate for this patient at this time. Studies have shown that the annual risk of stroke in patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis ≥ 50% is 0.5–1%.

F) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenting can be considered in patients with carotid stenosis who are not appropriate candidates for carotid endarterectomy, such as patients who have comorbidities that increase perioperative mortality. Compared to the treatment of choice, carotid artery stenting is associated with an increased risk of adverse events in patients > 70 years. This otherwise healthy 71-year-old patient should therefore be considered for a different next step in management.

G) INCORRECT:

Bilateral carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is not indicated at this time. CEA is indicated for asymptomatic patients with severe carotid stenosis. The right carotid artery is only 55% occluded and can be managed expectantly.
questions.hint: When choosing the next step in management, the degree of the stenosis, the patient's age, and the absence of symptoms should be considered.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He had no other symptoms and says he has never had a similar episode before. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and metformin. He is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 148/91 mm Hg. Visual acuity is 20/32 bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 15 mm Hg in the right eye and 16 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). The pupil is reactive and the cornea and anterior chamber are clear. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a few microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles, and bright yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery
Stenosis of the internal carotid artery
Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve
Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein
Stasis of blood in the atrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

Wet AMD can lead to subretinal hemorrhage, manifesting with acute monocular visual impairment. This patient does not have subretinal hemorrhage or any other signs of wet AMD (e.g., gray-green retinal discoloration, serous detachment of the retina) on fundoscopic examination and contrary to this patient's presentation, visual impairment after subretinal hemorrhage resolves slowly over several weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated demyelination of the optic nerve (i.e., optic neuritis) typically manifests with monocular vision loss with a progressive onset over hours/days and a peak in impairment after 1–2 weeks, unlike this patient's presentation with amaurosis fugax. Patients with optic neuritis develop papilledema (in the case of papillitis) or have normal fundoscopic findings (in the case of retrobulbar neuritis).
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the left eye of a patient with acute vision loss and painful eye movements

Discrete optic disc edema is visible: Discrete blurring of the nasal superior, superior, and temporal superior disc margin can be seen (green overlay). Otherwise, the fundus is normal.

This finding, in addition to the patient's symptoms, suggests papillitis in optic neuritis.

M: macula; circle: optic disc

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). His fundoscopic examination shows Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles), which are consistent with cholesterol crystal embolization. He also has signs of hypertensive retinopathy (e.g., microaneurysms, increased tortuosity of the retinal arterioles).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for recurrent spells. One spell involved a transient loss of vision in her left eye; others have consisted of recurrent episodes of transient right arm and hand weakness, each lasting less than 10 minutes. She has a medical history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and several previous myocardial infarctions (most recently 3 months ago) and coronary stents. Her medications include lisinopril, aspirin, high-dose atorvastatin, and metoprolol.
On examination, her blood pressure is 120/68 mm Hg. She has a late peaking, high-pitched carotid bruit on the left. The rest of her examination is unremarkable, and she currently has no arm or hand weakness.
A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are within normal limits. She has a total cholesterol level of 150 mg/dL (reference range, 125–200) and an LDL-cholesterol level of 67 mg/dL (<130).
A carotid-artery ultrasound shows 70% to 90% stenosis of the left carotid artery.
In addition to switching the patient’s aspirin to clopidogrel, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Switch the patient’s atorvastatin to rosuvastatin
Add dipyridamole to the patient’s regimen
Arrange evaluation by interventional radiology for carotid atherectomy
Arrange evaluation by a specialist for carotid endarterectomy or carotid stenting
Arrange for extracranial-intracranial arterial bypass surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has already had coronary artery disease and is now found to have carotid artery disease, her management plan should also include aggressive lipid control, blood pressure medication, and antiplatelet therapy. She is already taking high-dose atorvastatin and should continue it; switching to rosuvastatin, another potent statin, is not sufficient in isolation to manage her symptomatic carotid artery disease. Her blood pressure is adequate with her current medications, so no change is needed there. In terms of antiplatelet therapy, she was already taking aspirin and is now being switched to clopidogrel, which is reasonable given evidence of its slightly higher efficacy in secondary stroke prevention.

B) INCORRECT:

Dipyridamole is an antiplatelet agent that is advantageous for secondary stroke prevention when used in combination with aspirin, but it is not used with clopidogrel. Short-term dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel and aspirin is recommended in certain patients, namely those with minor stroke (NIH Stroke Scale score ≤5) or high-risk TIA (ABCD2 score ≥4). The ABCD2 score is generated based on clinical features of the patient and the TIA. In this case, the patient is >60 years old (1 point) and has events that involve unilateral weakness (2 points) and last for <10 minutes (0 points), for a total score of 3. Dual antiplatelet therapy is therefore not indicated. Furthermore, the cause of this patient’s stroke is extracranial stenosis, so carotid intervention would be most appropriate regardless of the severity of her TIA and takes precedence over adjusting her antiplatelet regimen.

C) INCORRECT:

Atherectomy can be beneficial in limb salvage in peripheral vascular disease, but studies of carotid atherectomy are limited.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has symptomatic carotid stenosis with recurrent transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and is a candidate for carotid stenting or endarterectomy. Patients with symptomatic carotid stenosis have a better outcome when treated with either of these procedures than when treated with medical management alone. In addition, patients receiving rapid intervention (within 2 weeks of the neurologic symptoms) have a better outcome than those whose treatment is delayed.

The decision between carotid stenting and carotid endarterectomy should be made on a case-by-case basis. Endarterectomy is often preferred because stenting is associated with a higher risk of stroke in the periprocedural period, especially in older patients. However, both stenting and endarterectomy are similarly safe and effective at stroke prevention over the long term, and endarterectomy may have a higher risk of periprocedural myocardial infarction.

Key learning point: Patients with symptomatic carotid stenosis have better outcomes when treated with stenting or endarterectomy than when treated with medical management alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Extracranial-intracranial arterial bypass surgery may be indicated for carotid stenosis on rare occasions, but the most recent studies have shown no benefit from this surgery compared with medical management.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stage 4 chronic kidney disease reports that he completely lost vision in his right eye shortly after waking up this morning. He had no pain at the time and gradually regained his vision about one hour after the initial loss.
His current blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. His vision appears normal on visual-acuity and visual-field testing. He has a normal head and neck examination without carotid bruits. He has no murmurs, and his lungs are clear to auscultation. He has a normal neurologic examination, including normal strength and sensation.
Laboratory results are notable for a creatinine concentration of 3.3. mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3).
He has a normal electrocardiogram. CT of the brain without contrast shows no abnormalities.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient’s vision loss?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiogram of the brain with gadolinium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current stroke guidelines support the use of carotid Doppler ultrasonography in patients who experience transient monocular vision loss consistent with a transient ischemic attack (TIA). This test is used to assess for carotid stenosis in patients whose symptoms are consistent with involvement of a neurologic territory supplied by the left or right internal carotid artery. Vision loss is more likely to occur with a carotid source of embolus than with a cardiac source.

Key learning point: The best diagnostic test for a patient who reports having an episode of painless, complete transient monocular vision loss consistent with a transient ischemic attack is carotid Doppler ultrasound to evaluate for significant extracranial carotid artery disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) and CT angiography (CTA) should be considered when Doppler studies are unrevealing or not available. This patient's renal insufficiency is a relative contraindication for contrast.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) and CT angiography (CTA) should be considered when Doppler studies are unrevealing or not available. This patient's renal insufficiency is a relative contraindication for contrast.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilated ophthalmoscopy is less likely than carotid ultrasound to be diagnostically helpful in this case because the visual acuity and field testing were normal. Transient monocular vision loss can be consistent with eye pathology (such as acute angle closure glaucoma), but this would typically be associated with eye pain, and it would be most appropriate to rule out carotid stenosis first.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasive cerebral angiography offers the advantage of improved visualization of intracranial vessels and can be considered if prior brain imaging is inconclusive. However, invasive procedures should be used only if noninvasive studies are unrevealing.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department 45 minutes after a sudden transient loss of vision in his right eye. The vision loss was painless and lasted for 5 minutes. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 48 years. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h. ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

C) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
Image Description:

Fundus photography of the right eye of a 76-year-old patient

Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage is visible in all four quadrants (example indicated by green outline). The tortuous veins (green arrows) are markedly dilated and there is papilledema with loss of sharp demarcation of the optic disc (green overlay).

These findings are typical for a central retinal vein occlusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.
Image Description:

MR angiography (right carotid artery)

There is severe stenosis (hatched green overlay) of the proximal internal carotid artery.

1: superior thyroid artery; 2: lingual artery; 3: facial artery
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of stage 4 chronic kidney disease reports that he completely lost vision in his right eye shortly after waking up this morning. He had no pain at the time and gradually regained his vision about one hour after the initial loss. His vision appears normal on visual-acuity and visual-field testing. He has a normal neurologic examination, including normal strength and sensation. Laboratory results are notable for a creatinine concentration of 3.3 mg/dL. CT of the brain without contrast shows no abnormalities. Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient’s vision loss?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiogram with contrast of the brain

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Current stroke guidelines support the use of carotid Doppler ultrasonography in patients who experience transient monocular vision loss consistent with a transient ischemic attack (TIA). This test is used to assess for carotid stenosis in patients whose symptoms are consistent with involvement of a neurologic territory supplied by the left or right internal carotid artery. Vision loss is more likely to occur with a carotid source of embolus than with a cardiac source.

Key learning point: The best diagnostic test for a patient who reports having an episode of painless, complete transient monocular vision loss consistent with a transient ischemic attack is carotid Doppler ultrasound to evaluate for significant extracranial carotid artery disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) should be considered when the most appropriate study for evaluating TIA is unrevealing or not available. This patient's renal insufficiency is a relative contraindication for contrast.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography (CTA) should be considered when the most appropriate study for evaluating TIA is unrevealing or not available. This patient's renal insufficiency is a relative contraindication for contrast.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilated ophthalmoscopy is less likely to be diagnostically helpful in this case because the visual acuity and field testing were normal. Transient monocular vision loss can be consistent with eye pathology (such as acute angle closure glaucoma), but this would typically be associated with eye pain, and it would be most appropriate to rule out carotid stenosis first.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasive cerebral angiography offers the advantage of improved visualization of intracranial vessels and can be considered if prior brain imaging is inconclusive. However, invasive procedures should be used only if noninvasive studies are unrevealing.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided weakness and subjective decreased sensation that started 30 minutes ago. The patient reports that his symptoms started to ease 5 minutes after onset and have now completely resolved. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. Neurological examination and head CT scan show no abnormalities. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and left axis deviation. Carotid duplex ultrasound shows 45% stenosis in the left carotid artery and 15% stenosis in the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks are not recommended because the patient has a high risk of stroke and requires treatment. Risk factors for cerebral ischemia in this patient include age > 60 years, blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg, unilateral weakness, diabetes mellitus, and symptoms lasting > 10 minutes.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended in TIA for symptomatic patients who present with carotid stenosis ≥ 70%. Carotid endarterectomy is warranted in asymptomatic patients if the stenosis is ≥ 80%. CEA should also be considered in select patients with moderate stenosis (50–69%) depending on the patient's age, sex, and comorbidities, but the procedure is generally not indicated if the degree of stenosis is < 50%.

C) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram should be part of the workup for a patient with TIA or stroke if there is suspicion of a cardioembolic etiology. This patient has no history of atrial fibrillation that would predispose him to a cardioembolic stroke and his ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, making a cardioembolic etiology of his symptoms unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel is recommended for all patients with a TIA as secondary stroke prevention. A noncontrast CT should be performed beforehand to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. Additional strategies for preventing recurrent TIA or stroke in this patient with carotid artery stenosis include statin therapy and treatment of modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) via lifestyle modifications (e.g., physical activity, dietary interventions, weight loss, smoking cessation) and medications.

Carotid revascularization (e.g., carotid endarterectomy, carotid artery stenting) is contraindicated if carotid artery stenosis is < 50% because the risks from the procedure outweigh any benefits.
Image Description:

MRI angiography (carotid arteries)

There is high-grade stenosis of the origin of the right internal carotid artery (red overlay). Visible major neck vessels (green overlay) include the common carotid arteries (1), internal carotid arteries (2), external carotid arteries (3), right superior thyroid artery (4), and left vertebral artery (5).

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alteplase therapy is recommended for the treatment of ischemic stroke. Although this patient has symptoms consistent with stroke (e.g., weakness and decreased sensation), the symptoms only lasted for 5 minutes; such a short duration is inconsistent with ischemic stroke.
questions.hint: This patient's sudden-onset focal neurological deficits that resolved without treatment in combination with no evidence of ischemia on neuroimaging suggest a transient ischemic attack (TIA), for which this patient has numerous risk factors (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, carotid artery stenosis). Two important factors for determining the management of carotid artery stenosis are the degree of stenosis (here < 50%) and if a patient is symptomatic (e.g., experiencing a TIA).

questions.text: You are seeing a 72-year-old man in the emergency department 45 minutes after he experienced a sudden, painless, transient loss of vision in his right eye that lasted for 5 minutes. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 48-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. Pulse is 72/min and regular. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals Hollenhorst plaques. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h (0–10). ECG shows regular sinus rhythm. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his loss of vision?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous inflammation of the ophthalmic artery is seen in giant cell arteritis (GCA). This condition may cause anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION), which can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax. However, patients with GCA usually have other symptoms as well (e.g., constitutional symptoms, jaw claudication, headache) and, most importantly, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Furthermore, AION due to GCA typically manifests with papilledema on fundoscopic examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Stasis of blood in the atrium, which occurs in patients with atrial fibrillation (Afib), increases the risk of atrial thrombus formation and arterial thromboembolism. Transient embolic occlusion of the central retinal artery would cause amaurosis fugax. However, this patient does not have an irregular pulse to suggest Afib, and thromboemboli, which are composed of platelets and fibrin, have a white-gray, pale, and nonrefractile appearance on fundoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) causes the formation of drusen, which are yellow retinal spots that can have a refractile appearance. However, these spots would be clustered around the macula rather than the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles and dry AMD does not cause acute visual impairment.

D) CORRECT:

Carotid artery stenosis (CAS) can manifest with monocular amaurosis fugax due to retinal ischemia, caused by stenosis-induced hypoperfusion, thrombosis, or microemboli. This patient has several risk factors for atherosclerosis (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking), and fundoscopic examination revealed cholesterol crystal emboli, which most commonly originate from carotid artery atheromas.

Workup for patients with amaurosis fugax generally includes carotid duplex ultrasound to screen for CAS. Carotid revascularization is indicated for patients with symptomatic (e.g., those with amaurosis fugax), severe CAS, and should be considered for patients with symptomatic, moderate CAS, and asymptomatic patients with severe CAS.

Key learning point: Transient monocular vision loss with Hollenhorst plaques is most often caused by retinal emboli from internal carotid artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic occlusion of the retinal vein (i.e., central retinal vein occlusion) typically leads to a sudden, monocular loss of vision. However, vision loss in central retinal vein occlusion usually does not resolve spontaneously. Furthermore, this condition manifests with massive retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous retinal veins, macular edema, and papilledema on fundoscopic examination, none of which is seen here.
questions.hint: This patient presents with painless, monocular amaurosis fugax (i.e., sudden transient vision loss). Hollenhorst plaques (bright, yellow, refractile bodies at the bifurcations of the retinal arterioles) on fundoscopy are caused by cholesterol crystal embolization.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness over the past 6 months. His medical history includes peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has a 50-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On auscultation, you detect a bruit on the right side of his neck. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Digital subtraction angiography of the neck.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is typically the first-line imaging modality for patients with symptomatic CAS (e.g., TIA, amaurosis fugax, ischemic stroke). Some guidelines also recommend ultrasonography of the neck to screen for CAS in asymptomatic patients with a carotid bruit and multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In patients with CAS, ultrasonography shows a focally-increased velocity of blood flow. Duplex ultrasonography is an inexpensive, noninvasive test with high specificity and sensitivity for the detection of CAS. It can also quantify the degree of stenosis.

Antiplatelet therapy, statin therapy, blood pressure control, and lifestyle changes (e.g., smoking cessation, weight control, regular exercise) are the mainstays of treatment in CAS. Carotid revascularization (typically with carotid endarterectomy) is indicated for patients with symptomatic disease and severe stenosis (≥ 70%).

Key learning point: Duplex ultrasonography of the neck is the first-line, noninvasive diagnostic test for evaluating suspected carotid artery stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with CAS, anticoagulants (e.g., warfarin) are not used for stroke prevention. Instead, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin, clopidogrel) are used. Warfarin is used for stroke prevention only in patients with certain risk factors (e.g., atrial fibrillation, prosthetic heart valves).

C) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography of the neck, which requires arterial catheterization, used to be the preferred test for evaluating CAS but it has been replaced by other modalities because it is an invasive and costly procedure that carries a ∼ 4% risk of iatrogenic neurological complications (e.g., stroke). Although it may have some utility in select patient groups (e.g., if the initial imaging modalities reveal discordant results or additional anatomic detail is needed), it would not be used as a first-line diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to identify cardiogenic sources of emboli in patients with symptomatic ischemic neurological disease (e.g., TIA) without a clear intracranial or extracranial vascular etiology. However, this patient's physical exam revealed a carotid bruit that is likely secondary to CAS. Echocardiography would not be the next best step for evaluating CAS.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography and MR angiography are not first-line imaging modalities in the workup of CAS, but they can be used to confirm the diagnosis if the first-line modality shows findings consistent with the condition or yields inconclusive results (e.g., due to significant carotid artery calcification). Angiography also plays a role in preoperative risk stratification and intervention planning.
questions.hint: This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes and hypertension presents with episodes of right-sided weakness lasting 15 minutes and left monocular vision loss lasting 5 minutes, both occurring within the past 10 days. His blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, and glucose is 140 mg/dL. Neurological examination is normal, and ECG shows sinus rhythm with no signs of acute ischemia. A carotid bruit is heard on the left. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality to determine the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated in this clinical scenario. This patient has classic symptoms of carotid territory transient ischemic attacks without signs of infection or subarachnoid hemorrhage to warrant cerebrospinal fluid analysis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has symptoms consistent with transient ischemic attacks in the left carotid territory (contralateral weakness and ipsilateral amaurosis fugax). The presence of a carotid bruit further supports carotid stenosis. Carotid duplex ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality for suspected symptomatic carotid stenosis and is essential for determining the degree of stenosis and guiding treatment decisions.

C) INCORRECT:

Holter monitoring is used to evaluate for arrhythmias that could cause embolic events, but this patient's pattern of symptoms (contralateral weakness with ipsilateral vision loss) is characteristic of carotid territory ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypercoagulability workup is typically considered only in younger patients with transient ischemic attacks and no vascular risk factors or identifiable cause. This patient has multiple vascular risk factors and clear territorial symptoms suggesting carotid stenosis, making another modality more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Echocardiogram is used to evaluate for cardiac sources of embolism after excluding carotid stenosis as the cause of these territorial symptoms. This patient's clinical presentation with unilateral weakness and ipsilateral vision loss strongly suggest carotid territory ischemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with hypertension presents with a history of right-sided weakness and speech difficulty that completely resolved after 45 minutes. She reports a similar but milder episode 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows a left carotid bruit and blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg. Noncontrast CT head shows no acute findings. Which is the most appropriate next imaging modality to determine the cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: CT angiography of the head and neck
MR angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is used as a confirmatory test if carotid duplex ultrasound findings suggest carotid stenosis, not as initial imaging. While CT angiography can provide simultaneous evaluation of head and neck vessels in patients with ischemic stroke, it is not the first-line test for suspected carotid stenosis.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Carotid duplex ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality for suspected symptomatic carotid stenosis. It permits direct visualization of the vessel wall and flow measurement at the site of stenosis by color Doppler ultrasound, showing focally increased velocity of blood flow in high-grade stenosis and increased peak systolic velocity. Recurrent transient ischemic attack symptoms in a patient with a carotid bruit indicate the need for urgent evaluation of carotid stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

MR angiography (MRA) is used as a confirmatory test if carotid duplex ultrasound findings suggest carotid stenosis, not as initial imaging. Although MRA has advantages, including lack of ionizing radiation and iodinated IV contrast, it tends to overestimate the degree of stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital subtraction angiography is considered only if carotid duplex ultrasound is inconclusive in patients who cannot undergo CT angiography or MR angiography, or for preprocedural planning. Digital subtraction angiography is an invasive procedure with higher risk of mortality and stroke compared to other imaging modalities with comparable diagnostic accuracy.

E) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler ultrasound is not the appropriate imaging modality for evaluating carotid artery stenosis. Another modality is indicated as the first-line imaging test for suspected symptomatic carotid stenosis in patients presenting with transient ischemic attack or stroke symptoms.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents for evaluation after an episode of painless, monocular vision loss in his right eye that lasted approximately 15 minutes before resolving completely. He describes it as a 'curtain falling' over his eye. He denies any associated headache, diplopia, or weakness. His blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg, and his pulse is 78/min and regular. On physical examination, a bruit is auscultated over the right carotid artery. The remainder of his neurologic and ophthalmologic examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study to evaluate this patient's condition?

choices.text: Computed tomography angiography of the head and neck
Magnetic resonance angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While once the gold standard, conventional angiography is an invasive procedure with a risk of complications, including stroke, arterial dissection, and access site hematoma. It is now reserved for situations where non-invasive imaging is inconclusive or as part of a planned endovascular intervention, such as stenting. It is not an appropriate initial diagnostic test for suspected carotid stenosis.

B) CORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the recommended initial diagnostic test for suspected symptomatic carotid stenosis because it is non-invasive, widely available, and accurately measures the degree of stenosis. Management, which may include carotid endarterectomy or stenting for severe stenosis (typically >70%), is guided by the degree of stenosis and the patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is a highly accurate method for evaluating carotid stenosis and is frequently used for preoperative planning. However, it is not the appropriate initial study. It involves radiation exposure and the use of intravenous iodinated contrast, which carries risks of allergic reaction and contrast-induced nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography is used to measure blood flow velocity in the major intracranial arteries, such as the middle cerebral artery. While it can detect the hemodynamic consequences of a severe proximal stenosis, it does not directly visualize or quantify stenosis in the cervical portion of the carotid artery, which is the suspected location of this patient's pathology.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) provides detailed imaging of the carotid arteries and is often used to confirm the degree of stenosis before surgical intervention. However, it is not the standard initial diagnostic test due to higher cost, limited availability, and contraindications in some patients (e.g., those with pacemakers).
questions.hint: This patient's transient monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) and the presence of an ipsilateral carotid bruit are highly suggestive of symptomatic carotid artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents after an episode of vision loss. He reports that one hour ago, while reading, he experienced a sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye, describing it as a 'dark curtain descending.' The episode lasted for approximately 10 minutes before resolving completely. His blood pressure is 145/88 mmHg and his pulse is 78/min and regular. Neurologic examination is nonfocal. On auscultation of the neck, a high-pitched bruit is heard. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Stenosis of the internal carotid artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vertebrobasilar insufficiency causes transient ischemic attacks or strokes affecting the posterior circulation. Symptoms typically include dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, ataxia, or bilateral visual disturbances. Isolated monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) is not a feature of vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

A cardioembolic source, such as atrial fibrillation, can cause a transient ischemic attack. However, this patient's pulse is regular, making atrial fibrillation less likely. Furthermore, the presence of a focal bruit on the neck provides strong evidence for a large-vessel atherosclerotic source in the neck rather than an embolic source from the heart.

C) INCORRECT:

A lacunar infarction is a small, completed stroke in the deep, penetrating arteries of the brain, common in patients with hypertension. These typically cause pure motor or pure sensory deficits and do not affect vision. This patient's symptoms were transient, which is not consistent with a lacunar infarction.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for amaurosis fugax, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) of the retina. This condition is caused by temporary occlusion of the ophthalmic artery, which is the first branch of the internal carotid artery. The most common cause is an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque located at the carotid bifurcation. The patient's risk factors (age, hypertension, hyperlipidemia) and the presence of a carotid bruit on the ipsilateral side strongly support atherosclerotic stenosis as the underlying etiology. The bruit indicates turbulent blood flow through a narrowed vessel. Carotid duplex ultrasound is the first-line imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis and quantify the degree of stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) also presents with sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, CRAO is an infarction of the retina, which results in persistent, profound vision loss, whereas this patient's symptoms were transient and resolved completely within minutes. This temporary nature defines the event as a transient ischemic attack, not a completed stroke like CRAO.
questions.hint: Advanced age, dyslipidemia, tobacco use, arterial hypertension, and diabetes mellitus are typical risk factors for developing this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for preoperative clearance for a scheduled coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery. He reports no history of stroke, transient ischemic attack, or amaurosis fugax. His medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes. Medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. On physical examination, a bruit is auscultated over the left carotid artery. A subsequent carotid duplex ultrasound shows 85% stenosis of the left internal carotid artery and 40% stenosis on the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's left-sided carotid disease?

choices.text: Addition of clopidogrel to current regimen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Optimal medical therapy, including antiplatelets and statins, is the cornerstone of managing atherosclerosis. However, for asymptomatic patients with severe carotid stenosis, the annual risk of stroke on medical therapy alone is high enough that surgical intervention provides a significant risk reduction. Medical therapy alone is insufficient due to the high degree of stenosis and the planned CABG.

B) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery stenting is an alternative revascularization procedure. However, for asymptomatic patients, large clinical trials have shown that carotid endarterectomy generally has a lower risk of periprocedural stroke and death. Stenting is typically reserved for patients who are considered high-risk for open surgery, such as those with a history of neck radiation, prior neck surgery, or a surgically inaccessible lesion.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has asymptomatic but severe carotid stenosis. In such cases, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended to reduce the long-term risk of stroke, provided the patient has a life expectancy of at least 5 years and the center's perioperative complication rate is low. The upcoming CABG surgery further supports intervention, as severe carotid stenosis increases the risk of perioperative stroke during CABG. Performing a combined or staged CEA with CABG is a common strategy to mitigate this risk. CEA has demonstrated a lower periprocedural stroke risk compared to stenting in most asymptomatic patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Adding clopidogrel to create dual antiplatelet therapy is not indicated for the primary prevention of stroke in patients with stable, asymptomatic carotid stenosis. This strategy would increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the context of upcoming major surgery, without a proven benefit over aspirin monotherapy in this setting.
questions.hint: For an asymptomatic patient, the decision to intervene on carotid stenosis depends on the degree of stenosis and the patient's overall life expectancy. The planned CABG adds another layer to the risk-benefit calculation.
